title.value: An improved column-generation-based matheuristic for learning classification trees
title.justification: The title of the paper is clearly mentioned in the first page as well as in the abstract and introduction sections.
title.quote: An improved column-generation-based matheuristic for learning classification trees

extractions.description: This paper proposes improvements to a column-generation-based heuristic approach for training decision trees, initially developed by Firat et al. (2020). The improvements include a modified subproblem model, data-dependent constraints used as cutting planes, an optimization model for generating these cutting planes, and a preprocessing and initialization routine. The results show that these modifications lead to faster training and better scalability for decision tree learning.

type.justification: The paper presents computational results showcasing the benefits of the proposed modifications over the previous column generation approach by Firat et al. (2020).
type.quote: We conclude by presenting computational results that show that these modifications result in better scalability.

name.justification: The paper focuses on improving decision tree models, which are widely used in the field of machine learning for classification problems.
name.quote: Decision trees are highly interpretable models for solving classification problems in machine learning (ML).

name.justification: The primary goal of the paper is to improve the learning of classification trees.
name.quote: Decision trees are highly interpretable models for solving classification problems in machine learning (ML).

name.justification: The improvements involve using optimization techniques like mixed integer programming and column generation.
name.quote: We introduce a modified subproblem model for the column generation approach with more variables and constraints than the one proposed in Firat et al. (2020) but requires fewer subproblems overall.

name.justification: The paper focuses on improving the learning of decision trees for classification tasks.
name.quote: Decision trees are highly interpretable models for solving classification problems in machine learning (ML).

is_contributed.justification: The decision tree model itself is not a new contribution of the paper. The contributions are the improvements applied to the existing column-generation-based heuristic approach.
is_contributed.quote: In this paper, we improve the Firat et al. (2020) column generation approach to make it faster and more scalable.

is_executed.justification: The paper presents computational results for training the decision tree models.
is_executed.quote: We computationally show the significant benefits of our approach with respect to Firat et al. (2020) on datasets from the literature.

is_compared.justification: The paper does not compare the decision tree model to other models but rather focuses on improvements to a specific training approach.
is_compared.quote: Instead, they try to address the scalability issues in the other optimization models for learning decision trees.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper is where the concept of decision trees in machine learning was initially introduced.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The standard ML algorithms for training decision trees, like CART (Breiman et al., 1984) and ID3 (Quinlan, 1986), use heuristics that optimize for one-depth level accuracies.

name.justification: The Tic Tac Toe dataset is mentioned as one of the small datasets used for computational experiments.
name.quote: The small datasets are also used in Verwer and Zhang (2019) and Firat et al. (2020).

referenced_paper_title.justification: The Tic Tac Toe dataset is a part of the UCI machine learning repository.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We used 12 datasets from the UCI repository (Dua and Graff, 2017) for our computational experiments.

name.justification: The scikit-learn library is used for running the CART algorithm, which is part of the initial path generation for the RMP.
name.quote: We used Python 3 for all computations, scikit-learn version 1.2.2 (Pedregosa et al., 2011) for running CART.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The scikit-learn library description and version is given in the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We used Python 3 for all computations, scikit-learn version 1.2.2 (Pedregosa et al., 2011) for running CART.

name.justification: The Gurobi optimizer is used to solve the restricted master problem (RMP).
name.quote: We used... Gurobi 9.5.0 (Gurobi Optimization, 2021) to solve the RMP (with or without integrality requirements).

referenced_paper_title.justification: The Gurobi optimizer description and version is provided in the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We used... Gurobi 9.5.0 (Gurobi Optimization, 2021) to solve the RMP (with or without integrality requirements).

name.justification: The CP-SAT solver from Google OR-Tools is used for solving sub-problems and for generating cutting planes.
name.quote: ...the CP-SAT solver from Google OR-Tools (Google, 2021) to solve the SPs ((2) or (3)) and to generate cutting planes by solving (8).

referenced_paper_title.justification: The CP-SAT solver description and its association with Google OR-Tools is provided in the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: ...the CP-SAT solver from Google OR-Tools (Google, 2021) to solve the SPs ((2) or (3)) and to generate cutting planes by solving (8).
